audio_caption: The audio begins with an announcement that today's video is sponsored by Squarespace. A single male speaker then describes the phenomenon of a blood moon, explaining that it's an evocative name for a total lunar eclipse. He states that this occurs when the Earth lines up perfectly between the sun and the moon, causing the moon to be completely covered in the Earth's shadow, and getting no direct sunlight.

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining why a full moon turns red-orange, reminiscent of blood, because of light from Earth's atmosphere still reaching it. He states that Earth's atmosphere refracts blue light, leaving a reddish-orange light on the moon, and each total lunar eclipse has slightly different color due to water vapor and particulate matter. Noises from a computer are audible in the background as he speaks.

The clip features a single male speaker, enthusiastically describing the upcoming blood moon in 2022 and providing tips for photographing future lunar eclipses. The speech is punctuated with moments of silence, and interspersed with a gentle, background music that enhances the information being conveyed.

The clip begins with a single male speaker giving advice, suggesting that the listener find out "the key times for when the eclipse starts and ends, including the different phases of the eclipse." The speaker's tone is informative and helpful. He suggests the website timeanddate.com as a useful resource, explaining that it seems to have good visualizations and graphics for determining the times for one's location automatically.

The clip begins with a male speaker sharing details about the timing of different phases of an eclipse, mentioning the penumbral and partial phases, as well as when the moon is expected to turn red. Speaking with an informative tone, he gives a second tip, which is to check weather forecasts and possibly relocate in order to see it. He then mentions the 2017 total solar eclipse, and how important it is to have backup plans in case of cloudy skies. Following this, he speaks about potential clouds and where to check weather conditions. Before he can share the last three tips, he introduces today's sponsor, Squarespace.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing Squarespace as a platform for designing websites, stating that he was "shocked by how fast" he could use it to revamp his website with professional templates. He then recommends it for anyone wanting "a nice professional looking spot" to share their astrophotography. The speaker also mentions a discount code for Squarespace. Following this, the speaker transitions to his next tip, focusing on picking and practicing with gear before an eclipse, suggesting that "you can get very cool shots with almost any setup."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the importance of feeling comfortable with the gear that you'll be using, especially for lunar photography, mentioning to remember the necessary steps and ensuring a clear understanding of how everything works. He suggests focusing on a bright star with a mask if that's how you're used to focusing, or you could focus on the craters of the moon itself, but to practice that first if you're not used to it. Sometimes, autofocus will work on the moon. He shares his personal gear plans, intending to use a lightweight setup with a new lens paired with his camera and a tracker, which he can set to lunar tracking mode. He notes that he may also use a wide angle or telescope. Finally, he encourages practicing with the gear ahead of time, to go in with a plan for what you want to accomplish and then to practice that plan.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing planning for photographing a blood moon, suggesting options from simple shots to complex time-lapses. He advises beginners to keep it simple and take many photos during totality to allow for stacking. The speaker's tone is informative and encouraging.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing camera settings for taking photos during a lunar eclipse. He suggests using these settings as a "rough starting place" because every eclipse is different, indicating an informative and slightly technical tone. He mentions adjusting the shutter speed and recommends shooting in RAW. A brief moment of silence concludes the clip.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the use of binoculars or telescopes for viewing celestial events. He emphasizes that seeing the stars and moon in the same field of view is special, and live viewing is preferable to photos, a sentiment he extends to eclipses in general. His tone is enthusiastic and persuasive.

The clip features one male speaker wrapping up a discussion, possibly about photography, as he mentions a follow-up on "processing your blood moon photography" and invites viewers to share their own tips in the comments, signing off with "Clear skies."
